entry.title: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Pro-tips for demonstrating SAP Fiori ‚Äì Navigate with confidence
entry.content:
TL;DR ‚Äì Tips and tricks for effectively demonstrating SAP Fiori as a functional consultant. Navigating confidently from app-to-app lets you focus on the business discussion around your demo. These tips are based on observing consultants in fit-to-standard workshops on an SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 system and working with them to improve their demo skills.

Here are some pro-tips based on real-life experiences for effectively demonstrating SAP Fiori in SAP S/4HANA, based on experiences with functional consultants. These suggestions can help you present SAP Fiori to your business users and provide suggestions for your change management team.  In this blog series you will find:

  • Researching your process (coming)
  • Organizing My Home
  • Navigating confidently ‚Äì this blog post
  • Showing extension possibilities (coming)

Navigating confidently across a process helps you and your audience focus on the business process under discussion, instead of worrying about which button or link to click next. 

For example, below is a Shipping Specialist confidently navigating from creating outbound deliveries from sales orders (a bulk process that can be scheduled) to reviewing one of the newly-created outbound deliveries straight from the log.

Pro-tip: You can see there is no need to search for the next app - just use the provided links in front of you.

Navigating from Create Outbound Deliveries to reviewing the delivery created

In this blog post you learn how to navigate across apps and features easily, including:

  • Quick intro to SAP Fiori insight-to-action navigation
  • Start with your process diagram
  • Start your demo from the most relevant page
  • Explain app-to-app navigation basics - including SAP Fiori to SAP GUI for HTML
  • Move smoothly to the next logical task
  • Minimize data entry for fast navigation
  • Start from a page when moving to a new role
  • Cool stuff to show
  • Show new versions of apps

These tips are based on workshops at a recent customer project where consultants were demonstrating the latest SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 and higher.  All processes were demonstrated from the SAP Fiori launchpad. The consultants had a range of skills from very/somewhat familiar with SAP Fiori to brand new SAP Fiori.

For this customer, nearly 100 SAP Business Roles were activated and test users generated for each business role. For a handful of processes, 5 additional custom business roles were created.

Many of our consultants had 50 or more business roles assigned to their own user id. This created several challenges for consultants:

  • Hesitant or awkward navigation that distracted the audience and lost the consultant‚Äôs train of thought
  • Overuse of Search on Apps and Favorite Apps
  • Missing the obvious navigation link that all the audience can see in front of you

In this blog post you will find examples for a Fit-to-Standard workshop based on SAP Signavio Best Practices Scope Item 1IU Consignment Stock in release SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02.

All examples in this blog post are taken from a SAP Cloud Appliance Library solution based on SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03. To access a similar system, read SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Create your SAP S/4HANA system in a fraction of the usual set...

 

Quick intro to SAP Fiori insight-to-action navigation

The idea behind insight-to-action is that when you see something that interests you, you can explore it further by navigating from app-to-app in an intuitive way.  For example, if you see an insight tile showing that there are 5 incomplete sales  documents, you can immediately drill-down to another app see which sales documents are affected and start taking some actions to get them to a better status.

Pro-tip: In demos, I usually refer to the insight-to-action behaviour as helping you follow your train of thought.

The term app includes wide range of launchpad content.  An app can be an SAP Fiori app, a classic UIs ‚Äì such as a SAP GUI transactions, Web Dynpro applications, WebClient UIs ‚Äì and any URL made available as a tile or link in the SAP Fiori launchpad.

Pro-tip: In demos, to explain how SAP Fiori launchpad can navigate across such a wide range of content, I use the phrase ‚ÄúThe new world knows about the old world and can cater for it‚Äù.   Conversely, I would also say ‚Äúthe old world isn‚Äôt aware of the new world‚Äù to explain how staying in SAP Logon restricts you from accessing the new innovations available via SAP Fiori. Not a perfect analogy, as there are some minor exceptions, but it‚Äôs broadly true especially from a business user perspective.

There are many ways you can navigate between apps of the SAP Fiori launchpad. For example:

  • Select a tile, card or link 
  • Select a To-Do or a Notification
  • Launch apps using Search on Apps or App Finder
  • Navigate to related apps from Search on objects
  • Many apps provide additional navigation via action buttons, Related Apps buttons, Navigate To menus, list of links dialogs, process/document flow cards, and so on.

Insight-to-action helps you apply your job expertise efficiently.  It is NOT:

  • Telling you what decision you should make ‚Äì although already in embedded AI use cases SAP Business AI will provide useful suggestions. For example, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, maintenance order recommendation
  • Stepping you through a process in a prescribed way ‚Äì although, if you need a refresher on how to run a process, this is where SAP WalkMe can provide self-service tutorials.

Insight-to-action respects role boundaries via authorizations ‚Äì you can only find and navigate to apps you are authorized to launch.  

Pro-tip: Similarly, within an app, you can only perform actions you are authorized to perform on data you are authorized to change. In demos, I use the phrase ‚ÄúAuthorizations always wins!‚Äù.  More explanation on authorizations later in this post!

Hint: SAP WalkMe and SAP Joule are rapidly growing additional features to navigate beyond the SAP Fiori launchpad. For example, you may need to complete a process in another SAP Cloud solution, such as a Procure to Pay process that moves between SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP Ariba.

 

Start with your process diagram

In our project, our expert functional consultants typically started each Fit-to-Standard workshop by showing the relevant process diagram.  This was effective in helping the audience understand the process and to flush out any top-of-mind queries or concerns. 

Pro-tip: If your demo is based on a best practices process, you can use SAP Signavio Process Navigator to show the BPMN process diagrams. If not, you can use another tool such as SAP Signavio Process Manager to create them. In our workshops both tools were used, by uploading relevant process diagrams from SAP Signavio Process Navigator to SAP Signavio Process Manager. The consultant adjusted the process where needed in SAP Signavio Process Manager.

Within the process diagrams, you can see the SAP Business Role at the top and side of each swimlane. You can also select a task to find which business role performs this task. Make sure you point this out!

In a SAP Signavio Process Navigator process diagram, the SAP Business Role is shown at the top & side of the swimlane, and can be found by selecting any task.

Pro-tip: Starting with the business role is important for your audience to imagine how the process will work in practice in their enterprise. It gives you an opportunity to discuss ‚Äúwho does this in your enterprise right now?‚Äù.  This early discovery made it easier to capture business requirements and consider which stakeholders would be impacted.

Pro-tip: Explain that the SAP Business Role is a pre-defined fully functional template of launchpad content and related authorizations provided as a starting point for refining your own custom business roles. Custom business role design is typically done later in your project as part of UX Design.

 

Start your demo from the most relevant page 

Starting from a page of the relevant business role gives the audience an initial sense of the business role so they can imaging how this process fits into a user's day-to-day life.  Is it a major or minor process? Is the task performed every day or only periodically or triggered by a business situation? 

Pro-tip: At the start of a demo, before selecting the first app, take a moment to explain that spaces and pages navigation makes the on-system tasks expected of each business role largely self-explanatory.   You usually only need to do this once per workshop.

  • Simpler, focussed roles may have a single page ‚Äì for example the Shipping Specialist. 
  • More complex roles ‚Äì such as the Internal Sales Representative - may have multiple pages to split tasks for different processes, periodic activities, analytics, etc. Often there is an ‚ÄúOverview‚Äù page which is the first page of the space and used for everyday/multiple times per day activities that need to be accessed quickly.

For scope item 1IU Consignment Stock, the process starts with SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders which is in the Internal Sales space on the Overview page - the first page in the space.  In the example below, you can see the consultant briefly show the pages in the space menu, then select the first app Manage Sales Orders, then smoothly navigate to the next app - in this use case SAP GUI transaction VA01 - using the provided action button Create Sales Order - VA01. 

Select the space Internal Sales, show the pages of the space, select Manage Sales Orders, navigate smoothly to the next app

Pro-tip: If the page you need is not the first page in a space, make it a favorite page. This gives you a single click to get to the page and introduce or reinforce the business role that starts your process.

Pro-tip: Reassure your audience that with your custom business roles these page layouts can be very easily adjusted to suit how your enterprise wants people to work.  Page layouts are edited using the WYSIWYG editor in SAP Fiori app F4512 Manage Launchpad Pages.  Layouts can even be shared or merged for similar business roles.  Refer to Learning video: Creating SAP Fiori Launchpad Layouts for Custom Business Roles.

 

Explain app-to-app navigation basics

As shown in the example above, it‚Äôs very common for processes to start from an SAP Fiori app called ‚ÄúManage <business object>‚Äù, for example "Manage Sales Orders". If it‚Äôs not the first app, most processes will use a Manage app somewhere in the process.  This provides the savvy consultant with an opportunity to make your audience comfortable with some basics of app-to-app navigation. Many Manage apps include navigations to other SAP Fiori apps and/or classic UIs, such as SAP GUI transactions and ABAP Web Dynpro applications. 

Hint: Naturally the more the use cases of a process are  covered by SAP Fiori apps, the less navigations to classic UIs (such as SAP GUI transactions) are needed.  SAP Fiori is focussed on innovations, so you should not expect SAP GUI transactions to disappear entirely.  

For the Customer Consignment Stock 1IU process in SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS02 the first step starts in SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders. You then select the action button Create Sales Order ‚Äì VA01 to navigate to the classic SAP GUI transaction VA01 where you create a sales order .

Pro-tip: If your audience is used to using SAP GUI, the first time a SAP GUI transaction is an excellent opportunity to explain how SAP Fiori launchpad brings a unified experience across new SAP Fiori apps and classic Uis.

Common audience & consultant questions at this stage of the demo are:

  • Why do I need to go through an SAP Fiori app? Can‚Äôt I just go directly to the transaction code? After all that‚Äôs 3 extra clicks.
  • What‚Äôs this app? What does a Manage app do?

This is where you can show your skill as a demonstrator!

Yes, you can go directly to any app that‚Äôs provided as SAP Fiori launchpad content of your business role(s). For example, using favorite apps or the tile Create Sales Orders VA01 on the Internal Sales Overview page or Search on apps.

  1. For those coming from SAP ECC, you can show Search on Apps using the keyword VA01.
  2. For any audience, show Search on Apps using the keyword sales orders and show that all the apps I can use for Sales Orders can be found via the search results.

You see both of these keywords demonstrated below.

Using search on apps using keywords VA01 and Sales Orders

However using Search on Apps to find apps is often NOT the most efficient navigation option! 

A good demo should leave your audience with an understanding of the optimal approach.  You explain that in SAP Fiori a common way to find and act on business objects is through Manage apps.  Manage apps act as worklists where you can filter, sort, prioritize, what you need to do, and then launch to the relevant action(s). You can also navigate directly to related information, for example information you need to decide what action you should take.

Pro-tip: In demos I usually say "Think of Manage apps as the ‚Äúone-stop shop‚Äù for that business object."

For example, in the SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders you can perform the following actions for Sales Orders:

  • Find sales orders by a wide range of criteria and sort/filter/group the list
  • Create ‚Äì using VA01 or using the embedded SAP Fiori app F3893 Manage Sales Orders -  Version 2 
  • Create with Reference to a Contract or Quotation
  • Display a graphical view of the Sales Order status
  • Navigate to any other related Sales Order app (that you are authorized to use) from the hyperlink on Sales Orders
  • Navigate to any other related Customer app that you are authorized to use) for the Sold-To Party, Ship-To Party, or Payer
  • Export the list of sales orders to a spreadsheet or PDF
  • Perform bulk actions for multiple sales orders, such as Set/Remove Delivery Blocks
  • Expand a sales order row to display sales order details and to perform further actions on the selected sales order.

You can see some of these actions in the example below.

Showing a variety of actions in SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders

Pro-tip: How to explain manage apps to participants with a background in SAP ECC

  1. Explain that in ECC you would often have 3 or more separate transactions to Create, Change, and Display business objects. For example, VA01 to create sales orders, VA02 to change sales orders, VA03 to display sales orders. You might have more transaction codes to remember for additional actions to block/release/etc. This is a significant cognitive burden on business users!
  2. In practice, when using SAP ECC many people would maintain cheat sheets of transaction codes that they would consult to work out which app to use. Given that the transaction code is simply a technical id that has no business meaning, that‚Äôs a lot to remember!
  3. With SAP Fiori, as a business user you can find the technical id ‚Äì for example using User Actions > About ‚Äì but you don‚Äôt need to remember it. You can find any app by name or partial name in Search on Apps, App Finder, etc.

Hint: At this point you may be wondering why this process is using SAP Fiori app F1873 Manage Sales Orders and not F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2. Scroll down to Show new versions of apps or TL;DR: Review the Feature Comparison for Creating, Changing, and Displaying Sales Orders

 

Move smoothly to the next logical task

When you are running tasks within the same business role, most of the time you want to move smoothly from one task to the next using the easiest available link or button in the current app.  Most apps provide several navigational options. These are supplemented by SAP Fiori launchpad features such as Search, To-Dos, and Notifications.

Pro-tip: The best navigation options pass the most amount of business context when moving from app-to-app. This avoids data re-entry which speeds up your process.  In order of most-to-least efficient, your best navigation options are:

  1. Action buttons are for primary actions ‚Äì including Navigate To menu buttons, To-Dos, and Notifications
  2. List of links are for secondary actions and side questions - including Related Apps buttons
  3. Search on objects is for ad-hoc queries and interruptions 
  4. Search on Apps is a last resort ‚Äì including favorite apps

 

Action buttons are for primary actions

These are usually the most obvious navigation option within an app.  They represent the primary actions expected from this app. They pass the current context to the target app. For example, values from the currently selected row(s).

If your app includes multiple rows and supports bulk actions, you may need to first select one or more rows on which the action is to be performed. This will be obvious.

For example, the action button Set Delivery Block is only available when at least one row is selected.

The bulk action Set Delivery becomes available when one or more Sales Order rows are selected

Pro-tip: The expand row icon ‚Äú>‚Äù is a very common table action provided with many apps.  You don‚Äôt have to select the icon itself to expand the row.  It‚Äôs an indication that selecting anywhere in the whitespace on that row will expand it.

Expand icon ">" indicates that the row can be expanded to see more details

Action buttons usually appear at the top of an object page, i.e. an app that describes a single business object. For example, you can perform many actions from the Sales Order ( app Change Sales Order) .

Action button Create Delivery is in the header of object page Sales Order

Hint:  You should be aware that technically an action may be part of the same app, or a navigation to another app. As a business user you don‚Äôt need to know this.  As a consultant, you can use the SAP Fiori launchpad > User Actions menu > About to check which is the current app and the designated application component for SAP Support. This is useful if you need to find related SAP Notes or raise an SAP Incident for the app.

Special action buttons:

  • In some analytical apps action buttons can appear as Navigate To menu buttons. Like other action buttons they will pass the current context to the target app.
  • To-Dos and Notifications can be treated in the same way as action buttons, because they pass business context when used.

Pro-tip: What values gets passed depends on what's in the context of the source app, what the target app can accept, and what's been configured in the technical Launchpad App Descriptor Item (aka LADI or target mapping). This is where it can get quite technical!  If asked about this, then I usually explain that in general, quite a lot of information can be passed from/to a SAP Fiori app, but most SAP GUI transactions can only accept a very small number of fields and don't pass any fields to other apps. 

 

Know the impact of authorizations on Action buttons

Action buttons always respect authorizations.  You must be authorized to perform the action on the data.  This is true regardless of whether the button is visible or not, and whether the button is available or not.  For example, if you don‚Äôt have access to Set Billing Block on the selected sales orders you will get an error message when you press the button.  

Hint: Action buttons are not automatically hidden as the combination of actions and data authorizations can be complex, varying from user to user and from use case to use case.

Typical audience questions at this point are: Can we hide that button altogether from some users? Yes! This is where Clean Core extension techniques such as Adapt UI, App Variants, and Adaptation Projects can be useful. 

Pro-tip: Avoid getting into the details of what‚Äôs possible in Fit-to-Standard workshops.  Extension option discussions are usually too technical for a business audience. Capture the business requirement and the business reasons behind it.  Ultimately, which technique will be used and whether the change will be made at all will be discussed at later stages of your project.

 

List of Links are for secondary actions and side questions

Within SAP Fiori, you can assume every hyperlink navigates somewhere. 

Many apps include list of links dialogs on business object ids/names, and even on process/document flow cards. These links take you to related apps, i.e. apps related to the same business object. They pass the business object id directly to the target app.

Pro-tip: Set your favorite links to match your audience expectations.  You can use the links immediately from the initial list of links and from the Define Link List dialog (which is reached by More Links).  Promoting your favorite links in the Define Link List dialog saves you one click each time for the links you use again and again.

In our workshops, participants often asked about the sales order status and follow-on financial documents.   It was helpful to promote the links Display Document Flow - Sales Order  and Display Process Flow AR - Sales Document  to answer these queries. You can see promoting and using list of links in the example below.

Adjusting list of links to set your preferred links

Pro-tip: The first link of the list ‚Äì i.e. the link on the object id ‚Äì displays the business object itself.

Related Apps buttons are essentially the same as the list of links dialog. They will pass the current business object id to the target app. 

Pro-tip: Personally, I prefer using the list of links dialogs in demos because when you have a lot of apps in the Related Apps list it can be harder to spot your next app. However, there‚Äôs not much difference in speed. Compare these 2 examples of moving from the Outbound Delivery to My Outbound Delivery Monitor ‚Äì which are both steps done by the Shipping Specialist.

This example uses the list of links on the Process Flow cards to move from the Outbound Delivery object page to My Outbound Delivery Monitor.

Using link lists from Process Flow cards

This next example uses Related Apps to move from the Outbound Delivery object page to My Outbound Delivery Monitor.

Using Related Apps to navigate from the object page to another app

 

Know the impact of authorizations on lists of links

Navigation links automatically respect your authorizations to launch apps.  For example, if there is a link provided on the sales order id:

  • If you have access to launch multiple sales order apps, you will see a list of links dialog with access to navigate to those sales order apps.
  • If you only have access to one other sales order app the link will take you straight to the other app.
  • If you only have access to the current app ‚Äì and no other sales order apps ‚Äì the sales order id will appear as a flat text without a link

 

Search on Objects is for ad-hoc queries and interruptions

The most overlooked option in the consultants running our workshops was the Search on Objects.  

From personal experience Search on Objects is a useful way to navigate when you have a query or interruption and need to jump back to find details on a business object id. 

It can be much quicker to find the business object id first, and then jump to the app you need, than the other way around - especially when you need to find ids based on partial ids or customer references.

With search on objects, you use fuzzy search wildcards to quickly filter and find the business object id.  Then you use search results to launch straight to the app you need.  Like List of Links and Related Apps, Search on Objects passes the current business object id to the target app.

You can see an example of using Search on Sales Orders for a partial Sales Order id in the screenshot below. Notice that the partial id is highlighted in the sales orders found in the search results. You can use the left-hand filter bar (funnel icon) to narrow down the search results if needed.  Expand the id you need to launch related apps passing the sales order id.

Search on objects using partial ids, names, or customers references with wildcards then launch the app you need from search results

 

Know the impact of authorizations on Search on Objects

There are more than 300 searches on business objects provided. Authorizations control which searches are available. Most consultants have far too many searches assigned! Reassure your audience that in real-life they would only see searches related to their business objects.   Like list of links and related apps, when you expand a search result only navigation links you are authorized to use will be shown.  

Pro-tip: The search result row header is a special navigation link to display object id itself.  For example, selecting  Standard Order 121 in the example above opens the Sales Order object page showing Sales Order 121.

 

Search on Apps & favorite apps are the last resort

Search on Apps will navigate to the app but does NOT pass any of the current business context. At best, you will have your Default Values applied when you launch the app from Search on Apps.  In an end-to-end process Search on Apps is the least effective option!

Pro-tip: Avoid Search on Apps when there‚Äôs any better navigation option available.

In one of our workshops, a consultant continually used Search on Apps even when there was a link in front of them that was obvious to all the participants.  For example, when transferring stock, a Material Document (aka goods movement) is created for you and a link is provided directly to the Material Document Id just created. Instead of taking the hint and selecting the link in front of them, out of habit they would go to Search on Apps, find the SAP Fiori app F1077 Material Documents Overview, and then use the filters to search for the document they just created.  That‚Äôs a lot of clicking around for no added value! By the end of the workshop, even the audience was pointing out the link! 

Pro-tip: When using Search on Apps, avoid entering the keyword manage! There are 100s of manage apps! When you are looking for a specific app it‚Äôs better to just enter the business object as the keyword e.g. ‚Äúsales orders‚Äù. For example, for the roles assigned, there were 355 Manage apps, but only 38 apps related to Sales Orders.

Hint: Find out how search on apps is changing in future releases in SAP Fiori Transforming User Experience: SAP Fiori Launchpad adopts the latest SAP Design System

Pro-tip: When performing an end-to-end task for the same role, avoid returning to the SAP Fiori launchpad My Home between apps. Like Search on Apps, launching from a space/page or from favorite apps passes very little business context.  At best, Default Values will be applied when you launch the app from Search on Apps. 

Pro-tip: You may need to use Search on Apps or favorite apps when moving from SAP GUI transactions to a SAP Fiori app. While a small number of SAP GUI transactions are able to include links to other apps, this is rare.  You can also use the Back button ("<" icon) in the shell bar to return to the previous app. 

 

Minimize data entry for fast navigation

Before your demo:

  • Set your Default Values for frequently used fields
  • Create App Views for apps that you will visit multiple times

 

Set your Default Values 

Adjust settings for fields that you need to enter multiple times across the process, such as Display Currency, Company Code, Plant, purchasing org, sales org.

For example, in our workshops, consultants would typically set their default organizational fields such as Sales Org, Distribution Channel, and Division. 

You set your defaults in SAP Fiori launchpad > User Actions > Settings > Default Values as explained in the SAP Fiori launchpad User guide section Maintaining your Default User Values

For more on what's possible with Default Values, refer to:

  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Yes Key Users can set Default Values for other Users
  • SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Synchronizing Default Values with Set/Get Parameters

 

Create App Views and name them by use case

App Views save you time by setting filters, tables, and charts for your use case.  The more often you use an app the more time you save by having an App View.  You can create multiple app views for each app.  

Pro-tip: Create App Views for apps with filters, tables, or charts that suit your process use cases.  Name your App Views after your use cases so they are easy to find and select. If you are showing multiple processes or have several workshops planned, each consultant can create their own app views in advance or as part of the demo.

For the Customer Consignment Stock 1IU process, the SAP Fiori app F1595 Stock - Multiple Materials is shown at least 3 times to check how consignment stock and free stock is impacted by the consignment fill-up, goods issue, and returns are processed. It‚Äôs helpful to create an app view to focus the app on the consignment use case.

Below you can see an example of how we used an app view we created before the demo for SAP Fiori app F1595 Stock - Multiple Materials.  You can see how easy it is to create or update it using the Adapt Filters, table settings, and the app view actions Save as to create an app view or Save to update it.

Select an app view, adjust the view's filters with Adapt Filters and/or the view's table settings, then Save to update your view

Pro-tip: Explain that one or more public App Views for common use cases of an app can be created via Adapt UI by key users (i.e. expert business users). Public App Views can be shared to all users of the apps or restricted to users with nominated security roles.  Refer to SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA ‚Äì Yes Key Users can create default app settings for filters, tables, and charts

Hint: One interesting question raised in our workshops was: Can public app views be maintained by someone other than the original author? For example, if the original author leaves the company.  We tested this and can confirm - Yes! - by using Adapt UI any key user who is authorized for Adapt UI for the app can maintain public app views.

 

Start from a page when moving to a new role

In our workshops some consultants would simply move from app to app without explaining that this task was done by a different role.  This frequently caused confusion for our audience who would start to ask ‚Äúso who does that‚Ä¶?‚Äù questions.  

Pro-tip: Show your Process Diagram again whenever you are changing roles ‚Äì or at least announce which role is runs the task. For example, when changing from the Internal Sales Representative to the Shipping Specialist. 

When you move to the Shipping Specialist role showing the Shipping space is a quick way to reinforce who is performing the next task

Announcing the business role also gives you an opportunity to discuss how they assign work ‚ÄúIn our scenario this would be done by the Shipping Specialist‚Ä¶ who does that work here?‚Äù  In our workshops, this question was useful to uncover special requirements around segregation of duties, device type needs, and other working conditions.  It can be very useful to capture the business context to inform the custom business role design in later stages. It also shows your audience you are interested in their unique enterprise perspective, which helps to build connection with your customer.

 

Cool stuff to show

SAP Business AI: If you have access, show SAP Joule ‚Äì the generative AI assistant. Joule provides capabilities to perform some actions in a conversational dialog. This can save having to navigate to an app at all ‚Äì or help you find the right app to use.

Collaboration via Microsoft Teams: in SAP Fiori apps using the Share button to share to email or share to Microsoft Teams chats, tabs, or cards.

Swap languages: Working with an international company? Discussing a process with a colleague in another country? No need to logoff - just change the language on-the-go in your SAP Fiori launchpad > User Action > Settings.  It's a quick way to encourage collaboration, break down language barriers, and simplify multi-country testing.

  • Pro-tip: From personal experience, make sure you know how the word English appears in your second language! I once changed the language from English to Thai and had to ask my audience which option to select to change back.

Show the context-sensitive help: When your audience are asking ‚ÄúWhat does this app do?‚Äù press the ‚Äú?‚Äù Help icon in the shell bar. This takes you to the App Documentation of a SAP Fiori app via the button ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs this app?‚Äù. For SAP GUI transactions, the help icon takes you to the SAP GUI transaction documentation.

  • Pro-tip: Context-sensitive help features for SAP S/4HANA are currently provided by SAP Enable Now and are expected to be provided by SAP WalkMe in future.

Handle error messages with ease: When you encounter an error/warning message, point out the error message area in the bottom left-hand corner of the screen. Expand the area and show the message long text, if available for your error messages.  Show how you can help resolve your own issues, including authorizations issues, through the self-service App Support.  From any app in the same user session, go to SAP Fiori launchpad > User Actions > App Support, review the log messages, and show downloading the logs to send them to your support team. 

  • Pro-tip: In our workshops we found App Support was a godsend in resolving technical issues quickly, by capturing all the relevant logs for the current user.

Never lose your work: Show an app with Draft capability such as F2499 Manage Customer Materials. If you get interrupted or change device your work is not lost even if the information is incomplete.  

Show keyboard navigation to improve entry speed by using the <TAB> key to move to forwards the next field and <SHIFT+TAB> to move backwards.

Resize the screen to show how the app will look on tablet or smart phone.

Convert a flat table to a hierarchical table: When you have an SAP Fiori app with a grid table (a table where you can adjust the column widths), use the table settings option Group By to create a hierarchical table.  For summable fields, your groups will show totals and subtotals. 

 

Show new versions of apps

When there are significant changes needed to an app, you may see a new app version released.  For example, F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 provides several benefits over F1873 Manage Sales Orders including:

  • Improved App View Personalization ‚Äì filter and table settings are consolidated reducing view maintenance, more filter criteria and table columns are offered to cover a wider range of use cases
  • Embedded and streamlined Create/Change of Sales Orders ‚Äì instead of having to navigate to transaction VA01. The streamlined creation includes simplified item creation, keyboard navigation, and copy/paste items from spreadsheet. During display/change, critical information is highlighted through embedded analytics. Refer to Journey of Managing Sales Orders in SAP Fiori ‚Äì Item Details
  • Default Values applied when creating sales orders
  • Simplified bulk actions for setting and removing blocks on orders
  • Improved search functionality including free text search
  • More extensibility options ‚Äì both Sales Order header and Sales Order Items support custom fields & data source extensions, Adapt UI for placing hidden and custom fields in all supported screens of the app
  • Intelligent Product Proposal when creating sales orders (optional)
  • Joule capabilities ‚Äì use Joule to fetch sales order information or create sales orders with reference then navigate to the app to see more details

Pro-tip: Often when there are overlapping apps, you will find a Feature Comparison document highlighting the main differences. For example, SAP Help - Feature Comparison for Managing Sales Orders and Feature Comparison for Creating, Changing, and Displaying Sales Orders

In practice, we could have used SAP Fiori app F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 for many of the steps in this process. For example, for Consignment Fill-Up.  In our workshops we did encourage use of this new app and used where we could. 

Pro-tip: Showing a new app version encourages your audience to think about how the process can improve over time.  

In our workshops we adjusted the sales order type configuration as explained in the Feature Comparison documents so we could show how creating sales orders works in the new version of the app.

Creating a consignment fill up order using the Create Sales Order action of SAP FioriF3893 Manage Sales Orders Version 2

So why isn't F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 included in the Customer Consignment Stock 1IU test script already?

It comes down to the app lifecycle.  When an app needs to provide a complex mix of use cases, it can take several releases to complete the full roadmap.

SAP Fiori app F3893 Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 was first made available in SAP S/4HANA 2021 with a lot of care taken over the new design. 

Pro-tip: You can find some nice screenshots and demos in the SAP Fiori apps library - but always test it in your own sandbox as features have improved greatly since the original release. 

Available means can start to take advantage of these new features where they fit your use cases.  Where both the original version and new version of the app are available, you can use either app or both. You can even control which sales order types can be created using the new version to gradually take advantage of the new app. 

Find which use cases are covered in SAP Note 3138511 - Order Types missing in 'Manage Sales & - Version 2' apps

Pro-tip: Once the roadmap is complete, typically the older version will be marked as deprecated to inform all customers that it‚Äôs time to shift to the new version.

There was one feature we needed for scope item 1IU that is not supported in SAP S/4HANA 2023, which is the Output Preview to check what information has been sent to the Customer. 

  • In SAP S/4HANA 2023, you can check the Output Items to confirm that the output has been sent, but you cannot see the Output Preview from the new version of the SAP Fiori app yet.
  • In practice, this means you need to navigate to the app Display Sales Order SAP GUI transaction VA03 to access the Output Preview feature.  This is not difficult, but as a user experience, it‚Äôs a little awkward.
  • Happily, Output Preview was included in the 2502 release of SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition, and we are expecting this feature will be made available in SAP S/4HANA 2025.

Hint: We had to tackle this question ourselves during our Fit-to-Standard workshops, where we had several different use cases for sales orders. Our customer was still deciding on their go-live release. They want to take advantage of innovations for this process where available.  In our workshops, we decided to use the new app where we could, and the older app only where we needed to, and to manage the queries from our audience who were already comfortable with the SAP GUI transaction VA01. 

 

Becoming a SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA guru

You‚Äôll find much more on our  SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA topic page

Brought to you by the SAP S/4HANA RIG and Customer Care team.

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start
entry.content:
This series of posts gives an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering our whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, SAP SuccessFactors, as well as covering  innovations in our UI technologies for building great UX.

In this first post, we‚Äôll look at the latest cross-suite UX innovations, coming from Joule, SAP Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start.

Before we get started: if you haven‚Äôt already seen them, do have a look at the overview of public cloud UX innovations I posted in Q1/2025 (parts 2 to 7 are linked in part 1):

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).

This upcoming series of posts includes Joule and AI UX highlights from individual products within the SAP Business Suite, but for a more comprehensive overview of our recent AI innovations, not just UX related, have a look at:

  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q2 2025.
  • SAP Sapphire Innovation Guide ‚Äì SAP Business AI.

 

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP systems, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access our cloud products and providing a seamless flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we‚Äôll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule stand-alone: Joule for Consultants
  • Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams
  • Joule Agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 1: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule ‚ÄúShow me sales commission by agend for model bike sales‚Äù, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 1, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 1 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as ‚ÄúWhat is the total revenue for Q1?‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow me sales by region in 2025‚Äù.
  • Comparative analysis, such as ‚ÄúCompare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?‚Äù
  • Time series analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me sales by month‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months‚Äù.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me top 5 sales by store‚Äù or ‚ÄúList the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales‚Äù.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 2 shows what this looks like.

 

Figure 2: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking ‚ÄúHow many languages does Joule support‚Äù. On the right, you see how active and expired conversations are shown. Alt Text: On the left, Joule replies with ‚ÄúJoule currently supports eleven language officially‚Äù and then lists them, below the answer a link to the source document ‚ÄúJoule Multi Language Support‚Äù is provided. On the right, the conversation history sidebar is visible on the left, overlaying half the screen, with a button ‚Äú+ New Conversation‚Äù at the top, followed by a section ‚ÄúActive‚Äù with two conversations and a sectin ‚ÄúExpired‚Äù with four. The bottom contains a link to ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù and on to ‚ÄúAI Notice‚Äù.

You can return to conversations within 8 hours. To start a new conversation, simply click on ‚ÄúNew Conversation‚Äù. The old conversation will be listed in the ‚ÄúActive‚Äù section, as you can see in Figure 2. The title of the conversation is automatically created by Joule using AI; users can rename the titles when they return to the conversation.  Joule supports a maximum of 10 active conversations.

After 8 hours, the conversation expires but is not deleted. It is kept read-only in the ‚ÄúExpired‚Äù section, as shown in Figure 2. Conversations are finally deleted 7 days after the creation date.

In the browser, Joule can be expanded to fill the screen, as shown in Figure 3.

Figure 3: Joule expanded to full-screen mode, showing the conversation history sidebar and the chat side by side. Alt Text: The same information is shown as on both screens of Figure 2, since the conversation history sidebar does not overlay the chat, and the chat is shown on the right with much more screen width.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Using the Joule Web Client.

Use Joule in 11 Languages

Figure 3 shows that you can ask Joule which languages it supports, and it will answer with the list of 11 languages. Here they are in alphabetical order, with the variant of the language in brackets.

  • Chinese (Simplified)
  • English (US)
  • French (France)
  • German (Germany)
  • Greek
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Polish
  • Portugese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Spain)
  • Vietnamese

Joule Stand-alone ‚Äì Joule for Consultants

In addition to providing Joule embedded in our products, we have a design pattern called Joule stand-alone, which we use for Joule for Consultants. With this pattern, Joule can be started directly, without first opening an SAP product and then opening Joule via the icon in the shell header. Joule stand-alone is opened in full screen, as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 4: Joule for Consultants using the Joule stand-alone pattern. Alt-Text: Joule full-screen, with one active conversation ‚ÄúCan you explaine about SAP Clean Core‚Äù, followed by a comprehensive answer, and scrolling options for reading the entire text‚Äù.

By supporting this pattern, people can open up Joule for Consultants directly and start asking questions about implementing or extending SAP products. Since in this case Joule is stand-alone, as the name suggests, the conversations you have there are not visible in the Joule instance that is embedded in our products, and vice-versa.

Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams

How often have you been in a chat with a colleague and needed to find some information from an SAP system? Up until now this would involve you leaving the chat, going to a different window and navigating to the right SAP application to get what were looking for.

Now, you can chat directly with Joule in Microsoft Teams, use Joule in Microsoft Teams and Microsoft Teams Mobile as an app, and ask Joule questions directly in Microsoft 365 Copilot. To get an idea of how powerful this is, watch this video:

To get started, have a look at the documentation:

  • Integrating Joule with Microsoft 365 Copilot

Joule Agents

We are bringing SAP Business AI to the next level via Joule Agents, that can autonomously plan and execute multi-step workflows.

Why do I include this in a section on user experience updates? Aren‚Äôt Joule Agents a back-end thing? Well‚Ä¶ the reason is simple: Joule Agents significantly enhance the overall user experience, as opposed to the user interface, because the system will do a lot more for you based on your requests. This means that the overall experience you have using SAP goes up a level, since you can get a lot done much more easily than before.

Joule Agents can be triggered from Joule directly, or embedded within applications. These four marketing videos show you examples of agents available today:

  • Finance: Dispute Resolution Agent (1:38 minutes)
  • Procurement: Sourcing Agent (1:48 minutes)
  • Sales and services: Account Planning Agent (1:24 minutes)
  • Human Resources: Performance and Goals Agent (1:34 minutes)

This example for customer service agents goes into more detail:

  • CX Agents (in SAP Discovery Center).

For a general overview of Joule Agents, have a look here:

  • Joule Agents on sap.com.
  • AI Agents in Action (blog post).
  • Envision the Future of Generative AI with SAP's AI Agents (blog post).
  • How SAP‚Äôs AI Agent Architecture Enables Unprecedented Automation and Decision Augmentation (blog post by Philipp Herzig).

Product-specific capabilities

In addition to the above generic capabilities, our products provide a large number of Joule skills for getting your work done more efficiently, as well as a handful of the new agents discussed above. For a comprehensive overview of Joule capabilities, including product-specific skills available today, here‚Äôs where to go:

  • Joule Capabilities (a 484 page (!) PDF document from July 11th, 2025, including a list of What‚Äôs New)
  • Joule Capabilities (online documentation)

Customer-specific Joule skills

You can now build your own Joule skills using Joule Studio, which has now been made generally available. Read Michael Ameling‚Äôs overview blog post:

  • Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation

Joule on Mobile Devices ‚Äì now for SAP SuccessFactors too

Joule has been available via SAP Mobile Start since Q1/2025 (as announced in this blog post), and is now also available directly from within the SAP SuccessFactors mobile app, supporting these three patterns:

  • Transactional: Joule can handle tasks like requesting time off, updating contact information, and even deleting phone numbers, directly within the chat interface.
  • Navigational: Joule can guide users to specific pages within the app based on their requests, such as directing them to where they can assign team goals.
  • Informational: Joule can access documentation and knowledge bases to answer questions about company policies, HR guidelines, and other relevant information, providing summaries and links to related resources.

Figure 5 shows two examples of the transactional pattern plus one example of the informational pattern (‚ÄúCan I use my private car for my business trip?‚Äù).

 

Figure 5: Examples of Joule on the SuccessFactors Mobile App. Alt Text: The image shows three examples: The first shows the response to the request by a manager ‚ÄúView time off approval‚Äù, with the details of one request, including the employee's name, the time-off period, and the type of time-off (vacation). The user can view the details, approve, or decline the request. The second screen shows a conversation where the user asks if they can use their private car for a business trip, and the system responds that they can, providing details on the reimbursement policy. The third screen shows the user requesting one day of vacation leave on March 3, 2025. The system confirms the request and provides the details of the leave, including the start and end times, and the date the user will return to work.

Find out more here:

  • Say Hi to Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile, Powered by SAP Build - Part 1: Unlocking AI for HR)
  • Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile: Getting Things Done with AI...
  • Documentation: Joule Available in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile - May 2025

Further information on Joule

If you want an overview of what‚Äôs new, or want to set up Joule in your landscape, have a look at the documentation:

  • Joule documentation (including What‚Äôs New, What is Joule?, integration guide)
  • What is Joule? PDF file

For an overview of what is planned, have a look at the road map for Joule in the SAP Road Map Explorer:

  • Joule Road Map.

 

SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone users and administrators benefit from these recent innovations:

  • New Side navigation for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.
  • SAPUI5 version preview.
  • Mobile Start supports Work Zone, advanced edition.

New Side Navigation

As I announced in April, in my blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), we are introducing some design updates to all our products in the SAP Business Suite to further increase consistency, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products ‚Äì no unexpected surprises. One of these is the introduction of a navigation menu on the left side of the screen.

SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition, is the first product to support this new design. Figure 6 shows what it looks like when the navigation menu is expanded, while Figure 7 shows it collapsed.

Figure 6: Side navigation expanded for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: A screen showing a SAP Build Work Zone screen with a navigation menu on the left with four entries ‚ÄúCentral Procurement‚Äù, ‚ÄúGlobal Support‚Äù, ‚ÄúMy IT Experience‚Äù (selected), and ‚ÄúSelf Services‚Äù. On the right various cards are shown in a section ‚ÄúEmployee Information‚Äù.

 

Figure 7: Side navigation collapsed for SAP Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: similar to Figure 6, but with the navigation menu on the left collapsed to the width of an icon, with four icons shown representing the four navigation options.

SAPUI5 Version Preview

We have introduced a new feature that allows administrators to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone, two weeks before they are adopted in the productive environment.  Until now, the latest SAPUI5 versions were automatically adopted in production environments, which limited opportunities for early evaluation ahead of deployment.

By enabling the preview setting on specific non-productive sites, administrators can assess compatibility and performance with the upcoming version. This controlled testing environment helps identify and address potential issues, reducing the likelihood of disruptions in production. After the two-week preview period, the RTC version becomes the default, aligning all sites with the latest stable release.

When looking at the sites in the site directory, those sites for which the preview is switched on are indicated clearly, as shown in Figure X.

Figure 8: Site directory with a site where preview is turned on. Alt Text: the image shows a card from the site directory for a site called ‚ÄúPreview SAPUI5 Demo‚Äù with a green badge containing the text ‚ÄúSAPUI5 Preview Enabled‚Äù.

Read more about this feature in this blog post:

SAP Mobile Start Supports SAP Work Zone, Advanced Edition

When using SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, you can now access your Workspaces or Feed Updates. Tasks and Notifications from SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, are also integrated into SAP Mobile Start: they are shown next to your business tasks and situations in the To-Do sections and in the Notification Center. Figure 9 shows an example with notifications from the advanced edition.

SAP Mobile Start

Beyond providing Joule natively for mobile devices, SAP Mobile Start has recently introduced a number of user experience improvements with their 2.2 and 2.3 releases. In addition to supporting SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, as described above, the main new features are:

entry.title: Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
The 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition contains enhancements to popular AI features and new natural language interaction options that help you work more intelligently and intuitively.

We‚Äôve spent the past 6 months since the 2502 release working with your feedback ‚Äì from beta programs, to roundtable discussions in the Public Cloud Practitioner Forum, to one-on-one meetings with customers ‚Äì to learn how we can help you achieve more with the help of AI in your system. Let‚Äôs take a look at what‚Äôs new, update you on the commercialization of some features, and give you resources for getting involved with our upcoming beta program. 

Natural language filtering now supports a wider range of queries

The AI-assisted easy filter (first released in 2502) enables you to filter list reports in your SAP Fiori elements-based apps using natural language. This simplifies how you access the information you need and reduces the training time required to pick up new applications delivered by SAP.

AI-assisted easy filter enables natural language filtering of pages with lists of business objects. Here the user can filter for a given sold-to party using plain language rather than needing to know its key..

For 2508, we‚Äôve made a number of enhancements to make interactions with AI-assisted easy filter even more intuitive:

  1. Tables can be filtered without needing to know an object‚Äôs specific key. Instead, simply enter the name of the object you are looking for. The AI-assisted easy filter will map that text to the intended key and apply it to the filter fields for you, which is a much more natural way to search for information. In the event that there are multiple keys with similar names, you will receive results filtered for those names. As before, you can always refine your results in the input field or using the classic filtering.
  2. We‚Äôve also worked to ensure parity between the filter fields that can be applied using the AI-assisted easy filter and the classic filter bar. Some users had reported that, in some cases, AI-assisted easy filter would not apply queries to certain filters. This was caused by the fact that some of the filter fields used navigation paths to different entities instead of the main entity for the app. This scenario is now supported and you can filter on any property present in the classic filter bar.

My Home Personalization with Insights Cards supports more apps and a new way to query for cards

The ability to create Insights cards and quickly add them to My Home now supports 20 SAP Fiori apps.

AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for Insights cards was released as a Joule capability as part of its 2503 release. The functionality allows end users to query Joule for business data they regularly need using natural language. The output is displayed as a card that can be added to their My Home page for easy reference. This makes it easier for users to access information they need to make everyday business decisions and move processes forward.

This functionality was initially limited to 9 applications. With the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, this coverage has been extended to 11 additional applications. This gives users easier and wider access to the business data that is important to them. AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for Insights cards now supports the following applications:

  1. Find Maintenance Order
  2. Find Maintenance Order and Operation
  3. Maintain Bill Of Material
  4. Manage Business Partner Master Data
  5. Manage Customer Returns
  6. Manage Manual Reservations
  7. Manage Material Coverage (Version 2)
  8. Manage Outbound Deliveries
  9. Manage Product Master Data
  10. Manage Purchase Orders (Version 2)
  11. Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional
  12. Manage Sales Orders
  13. Manage Sales Orders - Version 2
  14. Manage Sales Quotation - Version 2
  15. Manage Supplier Master Data
  16. Manage Usage Decisions
  17. Material Documents Overview
  18. Project Control - Enterprise Projects
  19. Reproceess Failed Material Movements
  20. Supplier Invoices List (Version 2)

Users can now use natural language to create and add Insights Cards directly in My Home.

For the 2508 release, we have also introduced a new way to create Insights cards using natural language: you can access the feature directly from My Home. This gives users the flexibility to choose the personalization option that works best for them, giving them access to the information they need at a glance.

If you'd like to read even more exciting updates about features and functionality included in the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, check out the following fantastic blogs from my colleagues:

  • For a general overview of new functionality: Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release 
  • For a few more AI uses cases, some focused on particular business processes: Exploring AI and next-gen Cloud ERP innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 

Commercialization update: New Base AI includes common AI functions at no additional cost

For the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, a number of AI solutions have been added to its Base AI offering. This means that you can use the features absolutely free of charge. You simply need to sign the SAP AI terms here and SAP will handle the activation for you.

Included in the Base AI offering for this release are AI-assisted easy filter and AI-assisted smart summarization, as well as AI-assisted enterprise search (which allows you to look up data from the search in My Home). Give them a try!

Try out upcoming AI innovations in the 2508 beta

For customers looking to try out the absolute latest in AI innovations, registration for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition beta is still open. This is your opportunity to try out and give feedback on new use cases for AI in your system. The solutions up for beta testing are free to use for the duration of the program.  Below is a preview of some of the features that will be available. Please note: Customer/partner participation will be at the discretion of the Beta Testing Program team. Participants must use SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition productively. Future developments are at the discretion of SAP and their details and delivery dates may be changed at any time.

Resolve situations directly in My Home without navigating to applications

AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home allows you to quickly take action on business processes that need your attention directly in My Home..

The Situations tab in My Home provides quick summaries of business processes that need to be addressed in your system. Previously, this meant reading the alert on the tile, navigating to the required app(s), and making the required changes. With AI-assisted Smart Solution for Situations in My Home, we‚Äôre streamlining how you take action on these scenarios. You‚Äôll now be able to see a summary of the situation, start the relevant business process from quick actions on the card, and even make changes to the business data all without leaving your My Home page. This allows you to stay on top of your business and resolve potential issues even faster.

Streamline data entry in object pages

AI-assisted easy fill streamlines data entry by populating object pages based on natural language input (for example: emails or messages from colleagues).

Depending on your business scenario, SAP Fiori object pages can sometimes be quite complex. Data entry might mean filling a field at the top of the screen, scrolling for several sections to add more information, and so on. AI-assisted easy fill enables you to enter your updates into a single field using natural language. The solution then maps your input to the proper fields, highlights any potential inconsistencies that may need to be addressed, and ‚Äì after your review ‚Äì updates the fields. This will help speed up data entry and reduce training time for new users.

Resolve error messages with AI assistance

AI-assisted error explanation provides resolution recommendations to error and warning messages in your system.

Learning new business processes can be tricky. AI-assisted error explanation uses AI to generate explanations and suggest resolutions for errors that are triggered in your system. This streamlines how you handle errors and reduces training time, making you more productive and helping you pick up processes even faster; in addition to reducing your organization‚Äôs support load.

Search for applications you need using natural language

AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications allows you to search for applications using natural language.

When learning a new business process or stepping into a new role, it can sometimes be challenging to find the exact application you need to carry out a task. With AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for applications, you can search for the app you need using natural language. Simply type in what you need to do and get served the required application, which you can add to your My Home page with a single click. This allows you to access the applications you need without needing to know the exact application name.

We want to hear from you!

Whether you take advantage of the new free features in the Base AI package, subscribe to cutting edge technologies, or choose to take part in a beta program; we want to hear what you think about these solutions! Give them a try and share your feedback below or with the product team. Your experience is critical to understanding how we can make these innovations even better for you.

When you‚Äôre ready to get involved, you can:

  1. Register to use base AI features
  2. Sign up for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition beta
  3. Join the Public Cloud Practitioner Forum (for customers live on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)

Happy experimenting! We‚Äôll be back with another update for the 2602 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

entry.title: SAP Community Escape House for August - Fiori Element with Flexible Programming Model
entry.content:
The eighth edition of the SAP Developer Challenge 2025 has officially kicked off!  A brand-new room has opened its doors inside the SAP Community Escape House.  Hope you all escaped alive from the SAP Application Event Hub room last month. 

In this developer challenge, we are focusing on SAP Fiori Element and the Flexible Programming Model. We are going to cover topics like:

FPM - Extension Points

FPM - Building Block

FPM - Controller Extension

 

Prerequisite

You have to clone the repository from:

https://github.com/SAP-samples/fiori-elements-fpm-exercises-codejam.git

For this challenge, you will be working in the finished-bookshop folder. This folder contains a completed CAP project that serves as the starting point for exploring extensibility using the Flexible Programming Model with SAP Fiori Elements.

All extension tasks, including UI enhancements and controller customizations, will be implemented on top of this CAP project. Inside this project, there is an existing Fiori Elements List Report application named bookshop-ui, which serves as the foundation for this challenge.

You will extend this application using the Flexible Programming Model, applying techniques such as Fiori extension points, building blocks, and controller extensions to tailor the UI and behavior according to developer challenge.

 

How to participate

Visit the SAP Community Escape House and enter your numeric SAP Community user ID.

SAP Community Escape House

If you're unsure of your user ID, you can find it on your user settings page url.

Goto SAP Community Page. Click on Account and then select My content. You can find the community user ID in the web page URL. Once you see the SAP Community Escape House, select the SAP Fiori Element room and start exploring it.

 

The user interface of an escape room includes the room itself as well as a terminal. You can click the objects in the room to receive tips. Like in a real (physical) escape room, you will have to try out a few things and explore the room until you receive helpful tips and, eventually, instructions. These tips and instructions are printed in the terminal next to the room. The terminal is also used to submit solutions to tasks. Read the instructions you receive carefully to understand how.

If you successfully escape the room (you will know when that happens), you will receive a badge in the SAP Community. We will assign the badges once the challenge closes.

 

The schedule

The SAP Fiori room will be unlocked on August 4th and will stay unlocked until the end of the year. However, the challenge closes on August 31st, so you must escape the room until then to qualify for a badge. Unlike the previous year, this SAP Developer Challenge does not consist of weekly sub-challenges. The next room (next challenge) will be unlocked in September.

 

Useful links for the challenge

  • Flexible Programming Model : https://sapui5.hana.ondemand.com/test-resources/sap/fe/core/fpmExplorer/index.html#/overview/introduction
  • Fiori Element OData V4 : https://developers.sap.com/group.fiori-tools-odata-v4-incident.html
  • FPM Code Jam : https://github.com/SAP-samples/fiori-elements-fpm-exercises-codejam/tree/main?tab=readme-ov-file

Good luck and happy escaping!
